1436735748028436480.text:
So what I am asking is that today, as you reflect on where you were on 9/11, you remember the unity felt in the days and weeks after that terrible day. 

As you go into next week, be kind to your fellow Americans. Be helpful. Honor those we lost 20 years ago today with unity.

1436735746799542275.text: It saddens me that we are a nation so divided now. We must embody the spirit of kindness and helpfulness without going through another tragedy to pull us together.

1436735745507594248.text: But more than the heartbreak & sadness, I was moved by the unity and kindness people displayed for one another. Strangers helping strangers. All of America rooting for New York & DC & Pennsylvania.

1436735744266194952.text: I knew it would be a difficult scene, but nothing can prepare you for that kind of carnage, the smoke rising from the wreckage or witnessing the despair of families still searching and hoping to find their loved ones.

1436735742693228552.text:
Like everyone else, I was terrified & heartbroken by this tragedy. I grieved for the people who never came home from work at the towers & the Pentagon, or their flight. 

I went to New York as soon as we could. I needed to see it for myself. I needed to see my friends & family.

1436735741468553220.text:
Whenever big, lifechanging events happen, we remember where we were or what we were doing that day. 

Illinois is my home now, but I'm a native New Yorker. My family & best friends still live there. They're the people I was thinking of when I heard the terrible news 20 years ago.

1436735738004058114.text:
It was an honor to attend and speak at a 9/11 Memorial Ceremony this morning in Park Forest.

The maternal health crisis reaches far beyond the tragedy of maternal mortality. For every maternal death, there are nearly 100 instances of severe maternal morbidity, or "near-misses." 

We need to implement evidence-based solutions to prevent these dangerous situations.

1390327833931694082.text:
Recently, the CDC released a report showing that the maternal mortality rate is rising.

More than two-thirds of the deaths are preventable. 

This is unacceptable, and the time for action is now.

1390326564076859394.text:
Black women are three times more likely and Indigenous women are more than twice as likely to die from pregnancy-related causes as non-Hispanic white women. 

We must address these disparities to ensure that women of color can have a safe and healthy pregnancy and birth.
